title: Scars Beneath the Skin
body:
I was a child with a heavy frame,
Mocked and teased, always the same.
Laughter echoed like a cruel song,
Telling me daily that I didn’t belong.

“Fat boy,” they’d chant in the schoolyard ring,
Each word a bullet, each insult a sting.
I learned to smile with a trembling face,
Hiding the cracks I could never replace.

They say “sticks and stones may break your bones,”
But words can bury you under heavy stones.
Every whisper, every jeer,
Became a prison I carried here.

I wore my shame like a winter coat,
Thick, suffocating, around my throat.
I searched for warmth in a cold disguise,
Yet found only shadows behind my eyes.

At night I prayed, “Lord, make me thin,
So maybe tomorrow, I’ll finally fit in.”
But the mirror replied with a silent sneer,
“You are the same boy they taunt each year.”

They told me, “Don’t cry over spilled milk,”
Yet my soul spilled daily, smooth as silk.
They said, “Time heals all wounds,” but I knew—
Some scars don’t fade; they grow with you.

Still, here I stand, broken yet whole,
Every crack in me carved a stronger soul.
They tried to drown me with rivers of shame,
But I learned to swim in my own name.

Now I speak for the lonely, the bruised, the small,
For those who feel like nothing at all.
You are not the insults, the laughter, the sneers—
You are the courage behind your tears.

So when life says, “When it rains, it pours,”
Remember—storms still wash the shores.
And though they broke me, I did not fall,
Because a wounded bird still learns to call.

My body was heavy, my spirit was too,
But I carried it all—and I made it through.
For pain is a teacher, cruel yet wise,
It plants deep roots so hope can rise.

And if you ask me the moral of my fight:
The darkest tunnels still lead to light.
For beauty is not in the weight you bear,
But the weight of the courage you choose to share.

                                                                                                        By: The Syntax Rebel

title: First Light
body:
Morning spills through open blinds,
A quiet cup, a page, a mind.
I write what sunlight cannot say,
And fold my doubts into the day.
